title: 111_s1560
content: The Act is titled the "Alaska Adjacent Zone Revenue Sharing Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that the United States is an Arctic nation with a 700-mile border with the Arctic Ocean, over 100,000,000 acres of land above the Arctic Circle, and a broader Arctic area including the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands. The Arctic region is home to an indigenous population that has relied on marine mammals, fish, and wildlife unique to the region for millennia, with a history of over 16,000,000,000 barrels produced. The United States Arctic region has produced over 16 billion barrels of oil and may hold an additional 30 billion barrels of oil and 220 trillion cubic feet of natural gas. Temperatures in the region have warmed significantly, the Arctic ice pack is rapidly diminishing, and the Arctic Ocean may be ice-free in 30 years. These changes are impacting the indigenous people of the Arctic. The United States Arctic region has significant oil and gas reserves, with warming temperatures leading to the rapid decline of the Arctic ice pack. This is affecting the indigenous people, communities, ecosystems, and wildlife in the region, opening up new areas for potential development in offshore oil and gas, commercial fishing, marine shipping, and tourism. SEC. 3. REVENUE SHARING FROM AREAS IN ALASKA ADJACENT ZONE. Section 18 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include revenue sharing from areas in Alaska Adjacent Zone, defining terms like coastal political subdivision and distance. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include revenue sharing from areas in Alaska Adjacent Zone. Terms like Indian tribe, leased tract, and State are defined. The State will receive 37.5 percent of bonus bids starting five years after enactment. The State of Alaska will receive 37.5 percent of bonus bids and post-leasing revenues from leasing rights in the Alaska Adjacent Zone. Additionally, 20 percent of the State's share will be allocated to coastal political subdivisions. The Secretary will allocate 20 percent of the State's share to coastal political subdivisions based on their distance from leased tracts within 300 miles. The Secretary will divide qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues among coastal political subdivisions based on their distance from the geographical center of the leased tract. 33 percent of the State's share will be directly paid to certain regional corporations. The Secretary will allocate revenues to Regional Corporations under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act based on the distance of Native villages from the leased tract's center. The Secretary will allocate revenues to Regional Corporations under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act based on the distances of Native villages from the leased tract's center. The revenues will be divided among qualifying Regional Corporations in amounts inversely proportional to the distances of all Native villages within each qualifying region. Each Regional Corporation shall treat revenue as subject to distribution requirements of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act and divide it annually among all 12 Regional Corporations. A Regional Corporation receiving revenues must further distribute 50 percent in accordance with the Act. The Secretary shall allocate 7 percent of the State's share directly to Indian tribes based on the distance of their headquarters from leased tracts. The Secretary allocates a percentage of State's share to Indian tribes based on distance from leased tracts. Qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues are divided among tribes inversely proportional to distances from headquarters to tract center. A conservation royalty of 6.25 percent of Federal royalty is distributed without further appropriation. The Secretary allocates a percentage of State's share to Indian tribes based on distance from leased tracts. A conservation royalty of 6.25 percent of Federal royalty revenues is distributed for land and water conservation fund or direct Federal deficit reduction.
